00070 #ifndef _POOLALLOC_INCLUDED_
00071 #define _POOLALLOC_INCLUDED_
00072 
00073 #ifdef _DEBUG
00074 #  define GUARD_BLOCKS  // define to enable guard block sanity checking
00075 #endif
00076 
00077 //
00078 // This header defines an allocator that can be used to efficiently
00079 // allocate a large number of small requests for heap memory, with the 
00080 // intention that they are not individually deallocated, but rather 
00081 // collectively deallocated at one time.
00082 //
00083 // This simultaneously
00084 //
00085 // * Makes each individual allocation much more efficient; the
00086 //     typical allocation is trivial.
00087 // * Completely avoids the cost of doing individual deallocation.
00088 // * Saves the trouble of tracking down and plugging a large class of leaks.
00089 //
00090 // Individual classes can use this allocator by supplying their own
00091 // new and delete methods.
00092 //
00093 // STL containers can use this allocator by using the pool_allocator
00094 // class as the allocator (second) template argument.
00095 //
00096 
00097 #include <stddef.h>
00098 #include <vector>
00099 
00100 // If we are using guard blocks, we must track each indivual
00101 // allocation.  If we aren't using guard blocks, these
00102 // never get instantiated, so won't have any impact.
00103 // 
00104 
00105 class TAllocation 
00106 {
00107 public:
00108    TAllocation(size_t size, unsigned char* mem, TAllocation* prev = 0) :
00109       size(size), mem(mem), prevAlloc(prev) 
00110    {
00111       // Allocations are bracketed:
00112       //    [allocationHeader][initialGuardBlock][userData][finalGuardBlock]
00113       // This would be cleaner with if (guardBlockSize)..., but that
00114       // makes the compiler print warnings about 0 length memsets,
00115       // even with the if() protecting them.
00116 #       ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS
00117          memset(preGuard(),  guardBlockBeginVal, guardBlockSize);
00118          memset(data(),      userDataFill,       size);
00119          memset(postGuard(), guardBlockEndVal,   guardBlockSize);
00120 #       endif
00121    }
00122     
00123    void GB_check() const 
00124    {
00125       checkGuardBlock(preGuard(),  guardBlockBeginVal, "before");
00126       checkGuardBlock(postGuard(), guardBlockEndVal,   "after");
00127    }
00128 
00129    void checkAllocList() const;
00130 
00131    // Return total size needed to accomodate user buffer of 'size',
00132    // plus our tracking data.
00133    inline static size_t allocationSize(size_t size) 
00134    {
00135       return size + 2 * guardBlockSize + headerSize();
00136    }
00137     
00138    // Offset from surrounding buffer to get to user data buffer.
00139    inline static unsigned char* offsetAllocation(unsigned char* m) 
00140    {
00141       return m + guardBlockSize + headerSize();
00142    }
00143 
00144 private:
00145    void checkGuardBlock(unsigned char* blockMem, unsigned char val, char* locText) const;
00146 
00147    // Find offsets to pre and post guard blocks, and user data buffer
00148    unsigned char* preGuard()  const { return mem + headerSize(); }
00149    unsigned char* data()      const { return preGuard() + guardBlockSize; }
00150    unsigned char* postGuard() const { return data() + size; }
00151 
00152    size_t size;                  // size of the user data area
00153    unsigned char* mem;           // beginning of our allocation (pts to header)
00154    TAllocation* prevAlloc;       // prior allocation in the chain
00155 
00156    // Support MSVC++ 6.0
00157    const static unsigned char guardBlockBeginVal;
00158    const static unsigned char guardBlockEndVal;
00159    const static unsigned char userDataFill;
00160 
00161    const static size_t guardBlockSize;
00162 #   ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS    
00163    inline static size_t headerSize() { return sizeof(TAllocation); }
00164 #   else
00165    inline static size_t headerSize() { return 0; }
00166 #   endif
00167 };
00168     
00169 //
00170 // There are several stacks.  One is to track the pushing and popping
00171 // of the user, and not yet implemented.  The others are simply a 
00172 // repositories of free pages or used pages.
00173 //
00174 // Page stacks are linked together with a simple header at the beginning
00175 // of each allocation obtained from the underlying OS.  Multi-page allocations
00176 // are returned to the OS.  Individual page allocations are kept for future
00177 // re-use.
00178 //
00179 // The "page size" used is not, nor must it match, the underlying OS
00180 // page size.  But, having it be about that size or equal to a set of 
00181 // pages is likely most optimal.
00182 //
00183 class TPoolAllocator {
00184 public:
00185    TPoolAllocator(bool global = false, int growthIncrement = 8*1024, int allocationAlignment = 16);
00186 
00187    //
00188    // Don't call the destructor just to free up the memory, call pop()
00189    //
00190    ~TPoolAllocator();
00191 
00192    //
00193    // Call push() to establish a new place to pop memory too.  Does not
00194    // have to be called to get things started.
00195    //
00196    void push();
00197 
00198    //
00199    // Call pop() to free all memory allocated since the last call to push(),
00200    // or if no last call to push, frees all memory since first allocation.
00201    //
00202    void pop();
00203 
00204    //
00205    // Call popAll() to free all memory allocated.
00206    //
00207    void popAll();
00208 
00209    //
00210    // Call allocate() to actually acquire memory.  Returns 0 if no memory
00211    // available, otherwise a properly aligned pointer to 'numBytes' of memory.
00212    //
00213    void* allocate(size_t numBytes);
00214 
00215    //
00216    // There is no deallocate.  The point of this class is that
00217    // deallocation can be skipped by the user of it, as the model
00218    // of use is to simultaneously deallocate everything at once
00219    // by calling pop(), and to not have to solve memory leak problems.
00220    //
00221 
00222 protected:
00223    friend struct tHeader;
00224     
00225    struct tHeader 
00226    {
00227       tHeader(tHeader* nextPage, size_t pageCount) :
00228 #ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS
00229          lastAllocation(0),
00230 #endif
00231          nextPage(nextPage), pageCount(pageCount) 
00232       { 
00233       }
00234 
00235       ~tHeader() 
00236       {
00237 #ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS
00238          if (lastAllocation)
00239             lastAllocation->checkAllocList();
00240 #endif
00241       }
00242 
00243       tHeader* nextPage;
00244       size_t pageCount;
00245 #ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS
00246       TAllocation* lastAllocation;
00247 #endif
00248    };
00249 
00250    struct tAllocState 
00251    {
00252       size_t offset;
00253       tHeader* page;
00254    };
00255    typedef std::vector<tAllocState> tAllocStack;
00256 
00257    // Track allocations if and only if we're using guard blocks
00258    void* initializeAllocation(tHeader* block, unsigned char* memory, size_t numBytes) 
00259    {
00260 #       ifdef GUARD_BLOCKS
00261       new(memory) TAllocation(numBytes, memory, block->lastAllocation);
00262       block->lastAllocation = reinterpret_cast<TAllocation*>(memory);
00263 #       endif
00264 
00265       // This is optimized entirely away if GUARD_BLOCKS is not defined.
00266       return TAllocation::offsetAllocation(memory);
00267    }
00268 
00269    bool global;            // should be true if this object is globally scoped
00270    size_t pageSize;        // granularity of allocation from the OS
00271    size_t alignment;       // all returned allocations will be aligned at 
00272                          //      this granularity, which will be a power of 2
00273    size_t alignmentMask;
00274    size_t headerSkip;      // amount of memory to skip to make room for the
00275                          //      header (basically, size of header, rounded
00276                          //      up to make it aligned
00277    size_t currentPageOffset;  // next offset in top of inUseList to allocate from
00278    tHeader* freeList;      // list of popped memory
00279    tHeader* inUseList;     // list of all memory currently being used
00280    tAllocStack stack;      // stack of where to allocate from, to partition pool
00281 
00282    int numCalls;           // just an interesting statistic
00283    size_t totalBytes;      // just an interesting statistic
00284 private:
00285    TPoolAllocator& operator=(const TPoolAllocator&);  // dont allow assignment operator
00286    TPoolAllocator(const TPoolAllocator&);  // dont allow default copy constructor
00287 };
00288

00290 //
00291 // There could potentially be many pools with pops happening at
00292 // different times.  But a simple use is to have a global pop
00293 // with everyone using the same global allocator.
00294 //
00295 typedef TPoolAllocator* PoolAllocatorPointer;
00296 extern TPoolAllocator& GetGlobalPoolAllocator();
00297 #define GlobalPoolAllocator GetGlobalPoolAllocator()
00298 
00299 
00300 struct TThreadGlobalPools
00301 {
00302    TPoolAllocator* globalPoolAllocator;
00303 };
00304 
00305 void SetGlobalPoolAllocatorPtr(TPoolAllocator* poolAllocator);
00306 
00307 //
00308 // This STL compatible allocator is intended to be used as the allocator
00309 // parameter to templatized STL containers, like vector and map.
00310 //
00311 // It will use the pools for allocation, and not
00312 // do any deallocation, but will still do destruction.
00313 //
00314 template<class T>
00315 class pool_allocator 
00316 {
00317 public:
00318    typedef size_t size_type;
00319    typedef ptrdiff_t difference_type;
00320    typedef T *pointer;
00321    typedef const T *const_pointer;
00322    typedef T& reference;
00323    typedef const T& const_reference;
00324    typedef T value_type;
00325    template<class Other> 
00326       struct rebind 
00327       {
00328          typedef pool_allocator<Other> other;
00329       };
00330    pointer address(reference x) const { return &x; }
00331    const_pointer address(const_reference x) const { return &x; }
00332 
00333 #ifdef USING_SGI_STL
00334    pool_allocator()  { }
00335 #else
00336    pool_allocator() : allocator(GlobalPoolAllocator) { }
00337    pool_allocator(TPoolAllocator& a) : allocator(a) { }
00338    pool_allocator(const pool_allocator<T>& p) : allocator(p.allocator) { }
00339 #endif
00340 
00341 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER >= 1300
00342    template<class Other>
00343 #ifdef USING_SGI_STL
00344       pool_allocator(const pool_allocator<Other>& p) /*: allocator(p.getAllocator())*/ { }
00345 #else
00346       pool_allocator(const pool_allocator<Other>& p) : allocator(p.getAllocator()) { }
00347 #endif
00348 #endif
00349 
00350 #ifndef _WIN32
00351       template<class Other>
00352          pool_allocator(const pool_allocator<Other>& p) : allocator(p.getAllocator()) { }
00353 #endif
00354 
00355 #ifdef USING_SGI_STL
00356    static pointer allocate(size_type n) 
00357    {
00358       return reinterpret_cast<pointer>(getAllocator().allocate(n)); 
00359    }
00360    pointer allocate(size_type n, const void*) 
00361    { 
00362       return reinterpret_cast<pointer>(getAllocator().allocate(n)); 
00363    }
00364 
00365    static void deallocate(void*, size_type) { }
00366    static void deallocate(pointer, size_type) { }
00367 #else
00368    pointer allocate(size_type n) 
00369    { 
00370       return reinterpret_cast<pointer>(getAllocator().allocate(n * sizeof(T))); 
00371    }
00372    pointer allocate(size_type n, const void*) 
00373    { 
00374       return reinterpret_cast<pointer>(getAllocator().allocate(n * sizeof(T))); 
00375    }
00376 
00377    void deallocate(void*, size_type) { }
00378    void deallocate(pointer, size_type) { }
00379 #endif
00380 
00381    pointer _Charalloc(size_t n) 
00382    {
00383       return reinterpret_cast<pointer>(getAllocator().allocate(n)); 
00384    }
00385 
00386    void construct(pointer p, const T& val) { new ((void *)p) T(val); }
00387    void destroy(pointer p) { p->T::~T(); }
00388 
00389    bool operator==(const pool_allocator& rhs) const { return &getAllocator() == &rhs.getAllocator(); }
00390    bool operator!=(const pool_allocator& rhs) const { return &getAllocator() != &rhs.getAllocator(); }
00391 
00392    size_type max_size() const { return static_cast<size_type>(-1) / sizeof(T); }
00393    size_type max_size(int size) const { return static_cast<size_type>(-1) / size; }
00394 
00395 #ifdef USING_SGI_STL
00396    //void setAllocator(TPoolAllocator* a) { allocator = a; }
00397    static  TPoolAllocator& getAllocator() { return GlobalPoolAllocator; }
00398 #else
00399    void setAllocator(TPoolAllocator* a) { allocator = *a; }
00400    TPoolAllocator& getAllocator() const { return allocator; }
00401 
00402 protected:
00403    TPoolAllocator& allocator;
00404 #endif
00405 };
00406 
00407 #endif // _POOLALLOC_INCLUDED_
